{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3561683,"name":"fovea1959","username":"fovea1959","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fovea1959/{size}/5301_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T14:26:48.534Z","cooked":"

I have a 8 year old roboRIO that had a very bad day, the CAN Weidmuller and the dual USB A ports are both busted.

One of our mentors has the capabilities to repair it. We were going to do a little hunting on DigiKey to see if we can figure out what the replacement parts are, but I thought I’d ask here to see if anyone knows.

I am not comfortable RMAing this because it was abused, but I hate to recycle it; it still good for running test code.

I don’t know about the can and usb-a connectors but incase anyone finds this post, usb-b connector for RIO 2 is this one: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/te-connectivity-amp-connectors/5788336-1/2188176

fovea1959:

the CAN Weidmuller and the dual USB A ports are both busted

You can live without the USB and deploy code and RoboRio imaging over Ethernet. We have a couple like this… CAN on the other hand, unless you use exclusively CTRE stuff through a CANivore or PWM motor control/traditional feedback only, you can’t really get around not having that port.

Edit: see below, I was thinking of the wrong USB port

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T16:38:41.312Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":59.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496201,"topic_slug":"lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements/496201/3","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561725,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T15:03:58.500Z","cooked":"

I believe the CAN Weidmuller is this:

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/weidmüller/1825640000/1094380

It’s the dual USB A, not the USB B. We use them for flash drives for a swap file and logging.

kingc95:

RoboRio imaging over Ethernet

Sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn’t. Couldn’t see any pattern as to the cause and instructions say use USB.

I believe you are correct! Thank you.

Have you tried contacting NI via the FRC support forum?
In previous years, I’ve had real quick turn around with them for replacement RoboRios - 1.0 and 2.0

I know you say its old and abused but might be worth a shot…

https://forums.ni.com/t5/Support/ct-p/Support?profile.language=en

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T16:12:03.335Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496201,"topic_slug":"lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements","display_username":"JBENJI","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://forums.ni.com/t5/Support/ct-p/Support?profile.language=en","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28067,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements/496201/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562193,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T19:21:40.976Z","cooked":"

I just replaced the CAN connectors with the part that @usbcd36 linked. The Roborio worked properly afterward.

It is easier if the plastic housing of the connector can be removed first by pulling upwards. The contacts for the two positions can then be desoldered and removed one at a time.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T19:21:40.976Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496201,"topic_slug":"lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":15648,"username":"fovea1959","name":"fovea1959","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fovea1959/{size}/5301_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements/496201/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562202,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T19:28:53.807Z","cooked":"

I agree with this procedure, and it’s the one we use at work for board repairs: destroy the part (gently) to give yourself the best chance to save the board. It helps if the part is already broken, like in this case. The trouble is when the part isn’t for-sure dead and someone lifts a pad.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T19:28:53.807Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":45.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496201,"topic_slug":"lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":15467,"username":"philso","name":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements/496201/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563051,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T16:50:16.331Z","cooked":"

It’s a through-hole part so the risk of lifting pads is much less than for surface mount devices. Someone with experience soldering should not have a problem. I would not recommend having a student do this repair due to the risk of damaging the board.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T16:51:35.867Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496201,"topic_slug":"lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lotsa-broken-connectors-on-a-roborio-replacements/496201/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563109,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T17:25:15.813Z","cooked":"

It’s of more limited use on surface-mount parts – clipping the leads of an attached device isn’t straightforward on many SMD packages.

I agree it’s not a difficult rework job, but I also wouldn’t take the higher risk option, given the cost of the board and the effort involved in trace repair. The cost of having to remove the shroud for individual desoldering is definitely worth it, IMO.

Did you do anything to remove the conformal coating over the can pins?
